instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v
threads.message:
Hey guys, liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> came in with 5V on the USB ports. I measure 3.4v on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. One thing, if I plug in the USB tester on one side it stays on at 5V, on the other side it keeps turning on and off. No CD's are getting hot, checked with thermal cam and alcohol. CB301 has some corrosion on it but not shorted. Liquid spil images for reference:

[url]https://s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/repairdesk/uploads/gallery/1055915746612620813511221389008106773.jpg.jpg[/url]

[url]https://s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/repairdesk/uploads/gallery/1056015746613934342832448554187186841.jpg.jpg[/url]

Most liquid around <CHIP>U4200</CHIP>, not sure what this does and if it is related to charge?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v
threads.message:
Compare diode mode readings around power rails of all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
A least one chips is suspect.
